definition: ticket/ballot/banknote/CL:張|张[zhang1]/person held for ransom/amateur performance of Chinese opera/classifier for groups, batches, business transactions

sentences.english: They rooked me of  ￡5 for the theatre ticket.
sentences.chinese: 他們將戲票轉讓給我，敲了我5鎊。

sentences.english: I just didn't want to waste the extra ticket.
sentences.chinese: 感謝你來纔沒有浪費那多出來的一張戲票。

sentences.english: Look at this, look. She buys tickets for plays that I wanna see.
sentences.chinese: 看她買的戲票是我一直想看的戲。

sentences.english: Theatre tickets are expensive so we only go to the theatre once in a while.
sentences.chinese: 戲票很貴，所以我們只是偶爾去看一場戲。

sentences.english: He has roped me in to help sell the theatre tickets.
sentences.chinese: 他曾動員我協助出售戲票。

sentences.english: Better presents than those involving packaging are "waste-free" gifts such as theatre tickets.
sentences.chinese: “無廢棄”禮物比帶包裝的禮物好，比如戲票。

sentences.english: You can book theatre tickets online.
sentences.chinese: 你可以在網上預定戲票。

sentences.english: This offer is applicable to the regular price of matinee and night shows.
sentences.chinese: 此優惠只適用於日場及夜場之正價戲票。

definition: to be up to one's ears in work (idiom)/to be unable to attend to other things at the same time
out of ammunition and no food left (idiom); in desperate straits
audition/dress rehearsal/preview (of a theatrical performance)/dummy run
Liehyu township in Kinmen County 金門縣|金门县[Jin1 men2 xian4] (Kinmen or Quemoy islands), Taiwan
fig. people who cannot afford to buy their own house
